This course provides a framework for studying the principles of management in organisations and its application in practice, particularly in the context of construction organisations. Management is the process of planning, organising, leading and controlling the work of organisational members and the use of available resources to achieve specific goals effectively and efficiently. The course focuses on how organisations are structured appropriately to the needs of the market, how leadership provides organisation vision and overall direction and how managers play a role in utilise an organisation’s resources (people, processes, systems and tools) for success. In addition, contemporary issues relating to management and the construction industry are explored. During the course, management principles are discussed during lectures and reinforced by interactive class discussion. Exercises, including formal assessments which relate to realistic management case studies, are used to support the learning aims.

General criteria are as follows: • A Case Outline will be provided for your Report. • Make sure you address the criteria described in the Research Report. • Be specific in addressing each item in the table below and justify your answers. • Submit to the FBE Student Centre.  • Report size: maximum 20 pages (excluding cover pages and appendices). • Late submission: 10% deduction of the total assessable mark per work day. Research assignment grades, along with feedback, will be returned to students about 4 weeks after the due date.

Closed book exam during the exam weeks. The questions will include short-answer questions and extended-response questions. Sample test questions will be provided to students mid-way through the course

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"020959b3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961939","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5e0959b3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9a0959b3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96193e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c20959b3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961936","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"460959b3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961920","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Class discussions and exercises","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Case studies and discussion questions will be given during the lecture times (typically in the second half of each lecture). In these exercises, students will be asked to discuss, in designated groups, their responses to the issues posed and to submit their discussion results by email to the lecturer, for review and feedback. Students are expected to apply management theories that are learned in the lecture to the exercises, to address the questions raised. Feedback may also be discussed in class during the lecture or in the following lecture. Online quizzes may be given throughout the semester. When an online quiz is uploaded on Moodle, students will be informed during a lecture and/or via Moodle and UNSW email addresses. Without special consideration or approval from the course convenor, students who miss a class discussion/exercise will receive a zero mark for that week. Each class discussion and online test contributes equally to the mark for Assessment 1.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"CONS0005","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CONS0005 - Construction Informatics","description":"

This course introduces and applies Information Communication Technologies (ICT) and Building Information Modelling (BIM) in the construction management discipline. This course offers knowledge and skills essential for successful adoption of ICT and BIM in construction planning, construction cost management, design coordination and modelling. ICT and BIM competences are becoming core requirements for design and construction professionals; this course covers the challenges and case studies of the adoption of ICT and BIM in the construction industry. It is structured around lectures, laboratory tutorial sessions; and assessment is based on both individual and group work.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6bed58fddb49bc10fe4b322af496194d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Computer lab exercises ","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

The computer lab sessions evaluate students capabilities of applying ICT, BIM and GIS principles and techniques for solving various construction management problems, including time, cost, quality, etc.

Conventional marking and feedback will be provided in the lab by the tutors.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"67ed58fddb49bc10fe4b322af496194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"67ed58fddb49bc10fe4b322af4961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6bed58fddb49bc10fe4b322af496194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"6fed58fddb49bc10fe4b322af496194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6fed58fddb49bc10fe4b322af4961950","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"27ed58fddb49bc10fe4b322af4961952","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Online quizzes ","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

There are two online tests focused on different aspects of ICT and BIM applications in construction management. 

Marks and feedback will be provided straight after the online quizzes.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"67ed58fddb49bc10fe4b322af496194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"67ed58fddb49bc10fe4b322af4961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6bed58fddb49bc10fe4b322af496194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"6fed58fddb49bc10fe4b322af496194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6fed58fddb49bc10fe4b322af4961950","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"63ed58fddb49bc10fe4b322af496195a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Major project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This is a group project consisting of 5 students in each group, which is aimed at demonstrating hands-on applications of the ICT, BIM and GIS technologies in problem-solving. 

This project consists of an integrated BIM model  and  a set of related documents completed by a group of students. This group component is worth 30% of total marks in the course). Each student will present their own contribution to the class; this individual presentation is worth 10%.

A group presentation and a CD/USB of BIM models and analyses for the given task.

There are consultation sessions with lecturers and tutors in the development of the group work. Feedback will be provided after the assessment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"67ed58fddb49bc10fe4b322af496194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"67ed58fddb49bc10fe4b322af4961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6bed58fddb49bc10fe4b322af496194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"6fed58fddb49bc10fe4b322af496194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6fed58fddb49bc10fe4b322af4961950","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7fed58fddb49bc10fe4b322af4961960","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

The objective of this assessment is to enhance your skills in reflective writing and professional communications.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"CONS0009","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CONS0009 - Construction Planning and Control","description":"

The course introduces students to various programming and scheduling techniques suitable for planning of long, medium and short-term projects and tasks at operational level. The course content provides the means for planning of both business as well as personal tasks. In particular, the students will develop skills to create a schedule of tasks and activities related to the construction of a building or other structures, to allocate appropriate resources to such construction activities, and to develop schedules of construction activities within the most optimum time and cost. The course is structured around lectures, computer laboratory and online sessions.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"13722a23dbf99850eb6b147a3a961969","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This is a group exercise consisting of 3 to 4 students in each group, which is aimed at demonstrating student ability to apply various planning and scheduling techniques on a real construction project. The deliverables are a set of project schedule plans and a comprehensive planning document.
Opportunity for consultation with course coordinator regarding the details and format of the planning document, and getting feedback / critique before final submission. Assessment is based on a group mark assigned by the course coordinator with consideration of peer evaluation on individual contribution to the group work.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"13722a23dbf99850eb6b147a3a96195a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"17722a23dbf99850eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5f722a23dbf99850eb6b147a3a96195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9b722a23dbf99850eb6b147a3a96195f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d7722a23dbf99850eb6b147a3a961962","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"03722a23dbf99850eb6b147a3a96193b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

There are four online quizes aimed to assess student understanding of various topics/ techniques covered in the relevant topics.
 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"13722a23dbf99850eb6b147a3a96195a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"17722a23dbf99850eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5f722a23dbf99850eb6b147a3a96195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9b722a23dbf99850eb6b147a3a96195f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d7722a23dbf99850eb6b147a3a961962","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"03722a23dbf99850eb6b147a3a96194c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Computer Lab Task","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

There are two computer laboratory tasks aimed to assess student skills in using commercial software in project planning and scheduling.
Opportunity for obtaining feedback from the tutors during the lab sessions. Marks will be given based on the observation and final check-up of the students' work by the tutors.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"13722a23dbf99850eb6b147a3a96195a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5f722a23dbf99850eb6b147a3a96195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9b722a23dbf99850eb6b147a3a96195f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4b722a23dbf99850eb6b147a3a961950","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam focuses on the individual skills on understanding and creating Critical Path Methods, Overlapping Network Model, Line of Balance, and PERT analysis etc. It also tests students on the overall project planning and monitoring skills.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"CONS0010","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CONS0010 - Construction Contract Administration","description":"

The course introduces students to procurement methods and the practice of construction contract management. Students will learn about: (a) different options for project delivery and the options for contract price; (b) the common matters covered in the general conditions of a major construction contract, including (but not limited to) practical completion, extension of time, liquidated damages, latent conditions, delay costs, bonus and variation clauses, insurances; (c) the relevance of legal concepts, including unjust enrichment, frustration, waiver, estoppel, frustration and repudiation to contract administration; (d) alternative dispute resolution methods; (e) the purpose and application of the Security of Payments legislation for construction; and (f) the relevance of the Australian Consumer law.

(Presentations approx. 20 min).

Students receive detailed feedback on their written assessment during face to classes. Ths feedback is designed to help students improve their performance in time for the submission of an assessment item. For this to occur students need to respond constructively to the feedback provided. This involves critically reflecting on advice given and in response.

This course involves a major assignment that provides students with the opportunity to demonstrate and integrate their professional construction project management knowledge and skills acquired throughout their Master of Construction Project Management (MCPM) Program. Students are required to develop a Construction Project Management Plan (CPMP) for a large-scale construction project. Students learn how to plan, execute, monitor and control a large-scale construction project utilising a CPMP.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"727dadf7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961989","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"In-class online quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

All the teaching materials, including lecture notes, are uploaded to Moodle a week before the class and students must explore them before coming to the class. Pre-class online Multiple-Choice Question (MCQ) quiz (not assessed) reflects student’s assimilation of the material. The two in-class online quizzes will assess students’ participation in before-class activities and in-class lectures. They are part of students’ assessment and they are collections of pre-class online MCQ tests. If students’ do the MCQ activities before each class and participate actively in lectures and tutorial sessions, they can expect to pass the two online quizzes in Week 5 and Week 9, 15% each. Feedback is an indispensable part of the assessment and feedback are provided to students immediately after submission of MCQs quiz in the Moodle. In addition, general feedback is provided to the whole class in the following week in the lecture and tutorial sessions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3e7dadf7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7a7dadf7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ee7dadf7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96194d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"527dadf7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961916","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group presentation (Individual 20% and Group 10%)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

To help students master construction project management techniques, students need to complete and present project management subsidiary plans in Week 10 in the Active Learning Spaces class time. Alumni or representatives from the construction industry provide professional and constructive feedback to students immediately after each team presentation. Each student needs to present individually in a team. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3e7dadf7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7a7dadf7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ee7dadf7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96194d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"aa7dadf7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96191a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Case-based group assignment (Individual 20% and Group 20%)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Students need to develop a Construction Project Management Plan (CPMP) as a case-based group assignment. Students need to work in a group to develop a CPMP and necessary flowcharts, subsidiary plans and documents to describe how the project will be executed, monitored and controlled. The CPMP covers project scope management plan, project schedule management plan, project cost management plan, project quality management plan, project procurement and risk management plan, project resource management plan, project communications and stakeholder management plan and importantly project sustainability, health, safety and environmental management plan. The CPMP will be assessed against a provided detailed rubric which is included in the course assignment brief and students will receive detailed feedback in 10 days following the submission via Moodle. Students need to specify their contribution in developing each component of CPMP to receive the individual mark (20%).

contentlets.description: This course involves a major assignment that provides students with the opportunity to demonstrate and integrate their professional construction project management knowledge and skills acquired throughout their Master of Construction Project Management (MCPM) Program. Students are required to develop a Construction Project Management Plan (CPMP) for a large-scale construction project. Students learn how to plan, execute, monitor and control a large-scale construction project utilising a CPMP.
contentlets.title: Construction Management Theory and Practice

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"CONS0016","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CONS0016 - Construction Risk Management and Business Analytics","description":"

This course provides guidance on characteristics and industry good practices of effective and efficient project risk management and qualitative and quantitative risk assessment methodologies as well as possible risk treatment options including contingency allowances. 


All projects and programs, especially within the construction and infrastructure sectors, face many external and internal factors and influences that make it uncertain whether they will achieve their tangible and intangible objectives.


Project risk management is an iterative process and assists organisations in setting strategy, achieving objectives and informed decision making during project lifecycle, from initiation to completion.


Providing a good practice approach to managing any type of risk, this course is not industry or sector specific. Its focus however is on commercial risks in delivering construction projects. Key risk categories such as work health and safety, environment, quality and other common risks throughout the project lifecycle are also discussed. By referring to good industry risk assessment tools and business analytics, including Palisade @Risk software and Office Microsoft Project (MSP), the course helps students to learn and practice how risk assessment techniques and business analytics can drive smarter engineering and construction risk-based decisions.

As part of the risk management team of XYZ Contractor, you are supporting the submission of a Design and Construct (D&C) Contract. You should undertake the required risk management and assessment activities including assessing the required cost and schedule contingency allowance for the defined scope of the project below from a D&C contractor’s perspective. You are required to research and find more details of this major project in order to successfully complete the assignment.

As risk manager of the project, you should prepare the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the project’s execution phase. You are required to research and find more details of this project to successfully complete the assignment.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"CONS0025","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CONS0025 - Infrastructure Planning, Procurement and Finance","description":"

Increasing Australia's global competitiveness will depend critically on the efficient procurement, finance, delivery and management of effective and high quality social and economic infrastructure. Experts from industry, government and academia will work with students to critically explore best practice from around the world in social and economic infrastructure planning, procurement and finance. Topics to be covered include domestic and international infrastructure markets and challenges; understanding the transformative role of new infrastructure design and delivery to growth, urban consolidation and renewal; the role of government in infrastructure planning and provision; project service definition; business case/ feasibility; financing structures; procurement options and processes; tendering processes; public sector comparator and other ways of assessing value; delivery; commercial principles; risk management and; contract management.
